etymology.description: 码(碼 ‘code; number’) + 农(農 ‘farmer’) = ‘code farmer’ → programmer (slang).
etymology.interpretation: Humorous metaphor likening programmers to farm laborers who toil for long hours doing repetitive work to ‘harvest’ code. Often self‑deprecating or slightly pejorative, highlighting the laborious side of coding.
etymology.simplification: Both characters were simplified in the PRC to reduce stroke count: 碼 → 码 (simplifies the 馬 phonetic and stone component), 農 → 农 (drastically condensed). The streamlined forms fit widespread Mainland usage in modern tech slang.

examples.chinese: 我是一名码农(我是一名碼農)。
很多人认为码农(很多人認為碼農)，工作强度很大(工作強度很大)。
examples.pinyin: Hěn duō rén rènwéi mǎnóng, gōngzuò qiángdù hěn dà.
examples.english: Many people think code farmers have very intense workloads.

examples.chinese: 在互联网公司里(在互聯網公司裡)，码农(碼農)常指程序员(常指程式員)。
examples.pinyin: Zài hùliánwǎng gōngsī lǐ, mǎnóng cháng zhǐ chéngxùyuán.
examples.english: In internet companies, manong often refers to programmers.
